Award.AwardTitle: Origin, diversification, and integration of nutrition-dependent development in horned beetles
Award.AbstractNarration:
The forms and functions of organisms and their parts emerge in development through the interactions between genetic inputs and environmental conditions. Changes in form and function, whether during development or evolution, must arise through changes in these interactions. This research seeks to identify and characterize which genes and developmental processes that (a) enable the differentiation of males and females, and (b) facilitate development in high and low nutritional conditions. Lastly (c), it investigates how changes in the interactions between gender- and nutrition-specific development allow the same traits in males and females to exhibit different responses to nutrition.

These objectives are addressed by advancing the study of a specific group of insects famous for how their development and evolution have been shaped by gender- and environment-specific differentiation: horned beetles. Horned beetle species differ greatly in the extent of male-female dimorphism (ranging from none to extreme) as well as nutrition-induced differences (ranging from none to gradual to discrete, akin to caste differences in ants and bees). Most importantly, horned beetles are easily kept in captivity and amenable to experimental analysis, including genetic manipulations and genome-wide expression studies. This research uses these approaches to investigate regulation and evolution of gender- and nutrition-dependent growth and differentiation. In so doing it addresses a fundamental, long-standing, and largely unresolved question in biology: how do genetic, developmental, and environmental mechanisms interact to shape the formation, integration, and diversification of complex traits?

This research interfaces tightly with several educational and outreach efforts. (1) Using a collaboration with a local children's museum this research will help provide training and educational resources in insect biology to approximately 200 local and regional K-12 teachers over the course of 3 years. (2) This research will help train at least 8 young scientists in intensive interdisciplinary research. (3) Lastly, it will facilitate educational outreach by helping recruit 8 high school teachers and 8 minority high school students for summer research immersion and introduce them to research in genetics, development, and evolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
All multicellular organisms including humans are composed of traits whose development is responsive to a variety of conditions. Two of the most important such conditions are (i) nutrition experienced during the growth phase of development, and (ii) whether traits develop in a male or a female. At the same time, this responsiveness is not uniform: some traits are greatly sensitive to nutrition while others are not, and some traits differ greatly between males and females, while others are essentially identical. This work, using insects as model systems, sought to determine the developmental mechanisms that enable organisms and their parts to exhibit variable, yet clearly controlled sensitivities to (a) nutritional conditions and (b) whether their development occurs within a male or female. Lastly, this work sought to understand (c) how such mechanisms originate and diversify in nature. Major results generated during the award period include (1) a more detailed understanding of a major developmental pathway previously known to be involved in the regulation of nutrition-responsive development, and (2) the discovery of two novel pathways previously not known to be involved in co-regulating nutrition and male/female responsive development. (3) Third, this work is among the first to show that organs whose growth is unaffected by nutritional variation achieve such so-called robustness by activating diverse compensatory mechanisms during development. (4) Forth, this work identified two developmental pathways as means by which physical traits such as morphology and behavior are co-regulated when nutritional conditions vary. (5) Lastly, this work is among the very first studies to document the genomic and transcriptomic mechanisms that enable species to diverge in the degree to which their development is influenced by nutrient availability. All results have been published in high ranking, peer reviewed journals, and all data have been made available in open access data repositories.

            At the same time this award enabled several significant training and educational efforts:  (1) Eight postdoctoral researchers, 4 graduate students, and over 20 undergraduate students received training in interdisciplinary biology. (2) Eight teacher-training workshops were carried out, introducing >140 K-12 teachers to newly developed teaching modules designed to enhance Indiana Science Teaching Standards. (3) The PI visited >150 classes in regional Elementary, Middle, and High Schools to help disseminate and model module implementation. Several of these teaching modules are now broadly utilized in South-Central Indiana thanks to the opportunities provided by this award. (4) Three summer programs directed by the awardee and executed every summer over the life time of this award enabled over 300 minority High School students to experience a progressively deeper introduction into the life sciences and independent, mentored research. These so called James Holland Programs identify high performing minority students in early High School grades across Indiana and neighboring states, then support and mentor these students until they are accepted into college scholarship programs. This approach, developed by the awardee, became fully institutionalized at Indiana University during the award period and will continue beyond the life time of this award.
